                          learning_rate = 0.01, 
                          depth = 5)

catb_tuned = catb.fit(X_train_scaled, y_train, verbose = False)


y_pred = catb_tuned.predict(X_test_scaled)
accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)

source.f82cc6da:
models = [
    
    log_model,
    rf_tuned,
    catb_tuned,
    
]


for model in models:
    name = model.__class__.__name__
    y_pred = model.predict(X_test_scaled)
    accuracy = accuracy_score(y_test, y_pred)
    print("-"*28)
    print(name + ":" )
    print("Accuracy: {:.4%}".format(accuracy))

source.b5e06d47: Target is not homogeneous. This can be a problem when preparing train/test dataset for model. Synthesis Route can be chosen just AC and others can be drop.
source.906f6f4e:
* Model importance show that VEC is the most important parameter for phases structure.
* Class imbalance affect its performance. SMOTE can help. 
* RandomForests gave the best result. 
* You can add new feature in order to be increase model accuracy. 
* Im phases includes different kind of structure(intermetallic, intermetallic, laves, martensitic, and other phases
but excluding glassy or amorphous and hexagonal close-packed –
HCP). You can fix Im phases or you can add new phases. 
* New features and new target phases(instead of Im) can be added to develop dataset and get a better result after modelling.
source.80bda1aa: RandomForests has the best accuracy. Target values are imbalanced. This situation can affect performance. So I used SMOTE to get balance. After smote I used the model that gave the best result.
source.30edd138:
High entropy alloys have recently attracted many researchers
due to the exceptional properties such as high hardness, corrosion resistance, cryogenic properties, etc. [1]. The HEAs have
been reported to possess solid-solution phases including face centered cubic (FCC) [2], body centered cubic (BCC) [3], or hexagonal
close packed (HCP) [4]. These unique structures are considered as
the dominant contribution to the excellent properties, including
good thermal stability [5], outstanding mechanical properties
[6,7], high hardness and wear resistance [8,9], exceptional
high-temperature strength [10,11], irradiation resistance [12,13],
excellent corrosion and oxidation resistance [14–15]. As such, these
alloys have been considered as potential candidates in many industrial applications.

Recent reports demonstrated the use of simple mixing [16], grouping strategy [17], empirical parameters [1], and CALPHAD aided prediction using Thermo-Calc® [18]. But to identify the domain, a large number of experimental trials and computational cost are required.

The HEA data available in the literature provides an opportunity to use Machine Learning (ML) algorithms for identifying the composition space or predicting the phase formation for a particular composition. ML is used in many fields of material science like energy applications [19], property prediction [20], etc. Recently Nusrat et al. [21] predicted the applicability of ANN for phase prediction in multi-principal element alloys and used around 118 compositions as a data set with an average predictive accuracy of
~80%. Huang et al. [22] used three algorithms such as K-nearest
neighbors (KNN), support vector machine (SVM), and artificial
neural network (ANN) with a data set of ~401 alloys to predict
HEA phase formation.
source.fcf08099:
* Logistic Regression
* Random Forests
* CatBoost

CrossValidation was applied to all models and best parameters were determined with model tuning.
source.efecfc81: Generally, the phase tends to maintain FCC crystal structure with VEC values greater than 8, and BCC crystal structure at VEC <6.87. When the VEC ranges from 6.87 to 8, a mixed combination of FCC and BCC phases is expected [26]. VEC has wide range for Im phases. There are not a specific range for Im phases.
source.2fada69d:
I created a new dataset from Ronald Machaka's HEA phase dataset. You can find entire dataset as a csv format in this study : https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352340921006302?via%3Dihub  

This dataset includes many diffrent process such as hot/cold working, annealing etc. after production. I prepared a new dataset by selecting the works that have not been processed after production.
source.d6a62dc7: There are many same data. Therefore, I droped duplicate data.
source.41ab4bcc:
* Num_of_Elem : Number of elements in a multi-component alloy system
* VEC : The valence electronic concentration of a multi-component alloy system calculated on the basis of the rule of mixtures approach
* Atom.Size.Diff : 	A parameter describing the atomic size mismatch or difference in a multi-component alloy system
* Elect.Diff : Pauling negativities mismatch for multi-component alloy system
* dHmix : Enthalpy of mixing for a multi-component alloy system
* dSMix : The entropy of mixing of a multi-component alloy system calculated as follows
* Sythesis_Route : A categorical feature indicating that the alloy was synthesised via vacuum melted (AC), powder metallurgy (PM), or otherwise
* Phases : Experimentally observed microstructure(s), namely BCC_SS (body-centered cubic solid solutions), FCC_SS (face-centered cubic single solid solutions) FCC+BCC_SS (dual-phase solid solutions) and Im (intermetallic, intermetallic, laves, martensitic, and other phases but excluding glassy or amorphous and hexagonal close-packed – HCP)

You can find more information about all of features about this data set in this study: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352340921006302?via%3Dihub
source.cdfa9f4d: We can see that some parameters are within a certain range(dSmix, dHmix, Atom.size.diff, elect.diff). The most notable among them is the distribution of VEC and number of elements. For the crystal structures of the phases, the valance electron concentration (VEC) has proven to be useful in predicting FCC and BCC type phases [24,25].
source.7b6df0ee: Sythesis_Route is same all data so I drop this feature.
source.cc83c2a0:
Solid Solution phases have a certain dSmix and dHmix range. We see that dSmix is less effective than dHmix in phase change. Since the contribution from mixing entropy is very small in the course of inter-metallic compound formation, the mixing entropy contribution to the free energy term can be neglected, and the mixing enthalpy become the main factor affecting the forming tendency and stability of inter-metallic compounds[27]. 
 
 * The less value of dHmix, the more stable it is.
 * dSmix is less effective for phase change.
 * VEC is the most effective parameter for phase change. (except Im phases, VEC has a wide range for intermetalic(Im) phases)
 * Atom.size.dif has a wide range for Im.
source.be6e1029:
Understanding the phase formation in HEAs is of great importance in the future work for new alloy design. Thus far, several formation rules and empirical criteria have been proposed to predict
the stability of solid solutions in HEAs, which was reviewed in the literatures [23]. Herein, some important factors, such as mixing enthalpy (dHmix), mixing entropy (dSmix), atomic size difference (δ), and VEC, should be particularly considered in alloy forming.
